Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Studying Exotic Nuclear Matter with a Particle Tracking Detector and Radioactive Beams
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports preparation and testing of a large detector for an upcoming experiment at the RIKEN Rare Isotope Beam Facility (RIBF) in Japan. This work will be performed with Dr. Hiroyoshi Sakurai, Chief Scientist of RIBF. The detector will be used to study exotic forms of matter produced by colliding radioactive beams only available at RIBF. Creating exotic nuclear matter in the laboratory has applications ranging from identifying and treating tumors, converting waste radioactive material into more manageable forms, to understanding the reason behind why matter is stable at all. There are hundreds of chemical elements that may be produced beyond that which can be found on earth. These elements are related to the naturally abundant elements in that they are heavy, or lighter, versions of the same element species. By adding or subtracting neutrons from an element, we can create exotic forms of matter which have interesting nuclear properties.

One of the future goals in the nuclear science community is to understand the asymmetric contribution to the nuclear Equation of State (EoS) which relates pressure, energy, and temperature of nuclear matter. This asymmetric contribution is related to the cost, in energy, you must pay when moving from matter that has an equal number of protons and neutrons to unstable, neutron rich matter. The highest uncertainty of the functional form of the EoS is around nuclear densities twice that of normal nuclear matter. RIKEN is currently the only place to access beams with high enough incident energy to produce collisions reaching this density. This project will prepare a Time Projection Chamber (TPC) to be operational for an upcoming experiment. In this experiment we plan to measure the light charged particles produced in these exotic collisions thus extracting information about the nuclear EoS. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The universe hosts an exotic form of material which does not exist on earth. This material is extremely dense and is made mostly of neutrons existing only in the form of a neutron star. To put things into perspective 1 teaspoon of neutron star matter would weigh about 1 billion tons on Earth. Such a massive, compact, object should collapse into a black hole. So there must be some internal pressure equalizing the force due to gravity. The origin of this internal pressure is due to the nuclear force. The nuclear force is repulsive for neutrons interacting with other neutrons. In fact matter prefers an equal mixture of protons and neutrons generally speaking. The fact that neutrons stars are made of nearly all neutrons give rise to this repulsive force balancing gravity.

     This dense, neutron rich, material can be produced in laboratory conditions for only a short time. In particle colliders where we collide two dense materials, such as Tin at high energies, we are able to reach these neutron star densities for fractions of a second. The forces involved in the collisions and the densities reached are reflected by the resulting particles produced in the heavy ion collision. By measuring these particles and determining their species and momentum we are able to speak about what happened in the collision during that short time frame. For this reason we have built the SpiRIT Time Projection Chamber (TPC) to be able to measure the light particle resulting from such collisions.

     Some of the major goals of this project were to gauge the performance of the finished SpiRIT TPC. Particle identification and the ability to be able to separate different species of particles is essential. Leading up to this large analysis task is first understanding energy loss. Another important goal was to see how well we can measure the tracks and their position in space. The position resolution puts a constraint on how well we can identify momentum. We also aimed to test the functionality of major components of the detector while looking for any possible issues.

     This project first started by looking at a simple analysis of cosmic rays. From this simple analysis stemmed a more detailed analysis that lead into the discovery of a major detector issue. Simulations were then performed to verify this issue. To mitigate this issue in the future, a calculator was made so that people could use it to set the correct values in the detector. I also confirmed the functionality of an integral component of the detector. This component acts as a physical gate on the detector signal, either letting in data or rejecting data. The experimental analysis and simulations were performed that confirm the full understanding of this component. The position resolution the detector was also extracted. We can now gauge how accurate we believe our momentum measurements to be and place meaningful uncertainties on particle identification. Also preliminary particle identification was performed. Although admittedly particle identification will be continued, and extended, under the efforts of many people in the near future.

       Overall the EAPSI experience lead to diagnosing significant issues early on that allowed for a successful commissioning experiment to test major components. I was also able to extract the detector's performance directly related to particle identification. The EAPSI experience was also one of cultural exchange and professional development. Building cultural connections and professional ones of which I am grateful for.
